text: I enjoyed it great to discuss in person, thanks <@UBS7QANF3> and <@U012XF5CNPN>

elements.text: I enjoyed it great to discuss in person
thanks
and

text: One of my favourite exercises for these llms in this context is to ask it to give me a flumine strategy for market making while managing overall liability and skew, and then I spend a few minutes looking at the result and spotting all the leaks and estimating how fast it would lose money. GPT-4 produced a solution that would lose a sizeable bank within an hour on UK racing. This one, actually might be flat. Not much needed to get it a little above flat. Impressive.

text: My model backed 1,000 in that race due to a data error so I got excited for a minute... But no luck, it was the 3rd :joy:

text: ```I have added these parameters and there's been a large boost to the log-likelihood. Yet the backtest looks largely unchanged. With a significantly better model, how can this be? What should I do next to improve the model?```

text:
This is interesting, it's an out of sample test in a way. 

I feel like current models are overtrained/perform on the popular testing suites, even after test updates. 

Do you run them through an actual backtest or just eyeball?

text:
<@U05N9773A23> was there a data error on that race then? (I was wondering why i hadn't placed any bets?)
If so at least I know that is working then :grinning:

elements.text:
was there a data error on that race then? (I was wondering why i hadn't placed any bets?)
If so at least I know that is working then

text: <@UQL0QDEKA> I had data coming through fine but there was a positional inaccuracy that caused me to place a very -EV bet that got matched at 1000. Happens regularly. It's amazing I manage to win- if I could filter out those scenarios I'd be making a huge return. But guess that's just the limitation of the data.

elements.text: I had data coming through fine but there was a positional inaccuracy that caused me to place a very -EV bet that got matched at 1000. Happens regularly. It's amazing I manage to win- if I could filter out those scenarios I'd be making a huge return. But guess that's just the limitation of the data.

text: How do you know that it is a positional accuracy? Do you replay it through something visual and compare with the race?

elements.text: How do you know that it is a positional accuracy? Do you replay it through something visual and compare with the race?

text: As the race progresses, I create a timeline of the the gps and market data along with my orders.  Once the market closes this is exported to json, 1 file per market. I have a script to pull down a chosen race and create some visuals. Also the fact I got matched at 1000 tells you all you need to know :joy:

elements.text: As the race progresses, I create a timeline of the the gps and market data along with my orders.  Once the market closes this is exported to json, 1 file per market. I have a script to pull down a chosen race and create some visuals. Also the fact I got matched at 1000 tells you all you need to know

text: Never had one go my way. I've had a 500 winner recently but the markets are so thin you don't cop for much

elements.text: Never had one go my way. I've had a 500 winner recently but the markets are so thin you don't cop for much

text: ???? Why is getting matched at 1000 a problem? I get matched at 1000 all the time?

elements.text: ???? Why is getting matched at 1000 a problem? I get matched at 1000 all the time?

text: I do similar and have software that replays the market from the recorded GPS but I very rarely actually review that anymore. The GPS is jittery at times - its just the way it is.

elements.text: I do similar and have software that replays the market from the recorded GPS but I very rarely actually review that anymore. The GPS is jittery at times - its just the way it is.

text: My model had the price much shorter than 1000 because the data showed it being much closer to the finish than it actually was. I actually hardly ever get dropouts or missing packets- I sub to multiple feeds and de-dupe. But I get the problems with inaccuracies all the time. I have some basic checks that act as a short circuit but only for obvious things... like runners not moving for a certain amount of time or going backwards

elements.text: My model had the price much shorter than 1000 because the data showed it being much closer to the finish than it actually was. I actually hardly ever get dropouts or missing packets- I sub to multiple feeds and de-dupe. But I get the problems with inaccuracies all the time. I have some basic checks that act as a short circuit but only for obvious things... like runners not moving for a certain amount of time or going backwards
